 The mass and lifetime of Bc meson have been measured by CDF ~\cite {AA06, AA706}  and DO ~\cite {VM08, VM09} in decays $B_{c}\rightarrow J/\psi \pi$ and $B_{c}\rightarrow J/\psi l$. CDF collaboration measured the mass to be $6.4 \pm 0.4$ GeV.  The majority of the $B_c$ mesons produced at the Tevatron are produced indirectly via the decay of excited $c\bar{b}$ mesons. The PDG mass of $B_{c}$ meson is $6.277\pm 0.006$ GeV ~\cite {KA,JB10}. The mass of the $B_{c}$ is very close to the arithmetic mean of the masses of the $J/\Psi$ ($c\bar{c}$, $3096.916 \pm 0.011$ MeV) and the $\Upsilon$ ($b\bar{b}$, $9460.30\pm0.26$ MeV), which yields about 6278.608 MeV. Heavy quark effective potentials predict the mass to be between 6.2 and 6.3 GeV. The mass of the $B_c$ has also been calculated using lattice gauge theory to be 6.4$\pm$0.1, where the uncertainty is dominated by the error from the omission of dynamical quarks \cite{HP99}. The first excited state is the spin-1 state $B^*_c$ , which is predicted to be heavier by 78$\pm$13 MeV. 1 $^3S_1$ $c\bar{b}$ level, with a total width of 135 eV, is far more stable than its counterparts in the $c\bar{c}$ and $b\bar{b}$ systems, whose total widths are 68$\pm$10 keV and 52.1$\pm$2.1 keV, respectively.  The most promising is the first radial excitation $B_c$(2S), whose mass is predicted to be higher than that of the $B^â_c$ by about 600 MeV.\\
